meeting_annotations.speaker: Allie Obermeyer
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I am Allie Obermeyer. I am an assistant professor in the chemical engineering department at Columbia. And my group broadly works in the protein and polymer engineering space. So we're frequently trying to engineer and understand protein interactions with both synthetic polymers and biopolymers. And so one of those type of interactions can or many of them, but one that we're particularly interested in can result in phase separation of proteins both in an in vitro system for applications in protein purification and formulation. But then also we have been engineering proteins to artificially control their phase separation inside of living cells. So we do this in bacteria and tuning electrostatic interactions to control phase separation to identify minimal sequences that can promote phase separation and then potentially use these for for engineering purposes. So yeah, so super interested in better better tools to understand the systems we're engineering and and yeah, how we can potentially use some of the things we've engineered to to probe some biological phase separation.
